00019 // Standard asserts.
00020 #define ASSERT_EQ(a, b)  ASSERT_CMP(Assertion::eq((a), (b)), (a), (b))
00021 #define ASSERT_NE(a, b)  ASSERT_CMP(Assertion::ne((a), (b)), (a), (b))
00022 #define ASSERT_GT(a, b)  ASSERT_CMP(Assertion::gt((a), (b)), (a), (b))
00023 #define ASSERT_GE(a, b)  ASSERT_CMP(Assertion::ge((a), (b)), (a), (b))
00024 #define ASSERT_LT(a, b)  ASSERT_CMP(Assertion::lt((a), (b)), (a), (b))
00025 #define ASSERT_LE(a, b)  ASSERT_CMP(Assertion::le((a), (b)), (a), (b))
00026 #define ASSERTS_EQ(a, b) ASSERT_CMP(Assertion::eq(std::string(a), std::string(b)), (a), (b))
00027 
00028 // Test asserts. This can only be used in void functions.
00029 #define TASSERT_EQ(a, b)  TASSERT_CMP(Assertion::eq((a), (b)), (a), (b))
00030 #define TASSERT_NE(a, b)  TASSERT_CMP(Assertion::ne((a), (b)), (a), (b))
00031 #define TASSERT_GT(a, b)  TASSERT_CMP(Assertion::gt((a), (b)), (a), (b))
00032 #define TASSERT_GE(a, b)  TASSERT_CMP(Assertion::ge((a), (b)), (a), (b))
00033 #define TASSERT_LT(a, b)  TASSERT_CMP(Assertion::lt((a), (b)), (a), (b))
00034 #define TASSERT_LE(a, b)  TASSERT_CMP(Assertion::le((a), (b)), (a), (b))
00035 #define TASSERTS_EQ(a, b) TASSERT_CMP(Assertion::eq(std::string(a), std::string(b)), (a), (b))
00036 
00037 // These should not get compiled out like standard asserts below.
00038 #define TASSERT(a) do { switch(Assertion::GetSingleton()->checkAssertion((a), "", #a, __FILE__, __LINE__)) { case 0: break; case 1: return; case 2: abort(); } } while(0)
00039 #define TASSERT_CMP(cmp, a, b) do { switch(Assertion::GetSingleton()->checkAssertion((cmp), (a), (b), "", #a, #b, __FILE__, __LINE__)) { case 0: break; case 1: return; case 2: abort(); } } while(0)
00040 
00041 // If DISABLE_ASSERT is defined, all non test asserts will be turned off.
00042 #if !defined(DISABLE_ASSERT)
00043 #   define  ASSERT(a) do { switch(Assertion::GetSingleton()->checkAssertion((a), "", #a, __FILE__, __LINE__)) { case 0: break; case 1: break;  case 2: abort(); } } while(0)
00044 #   define  ASSERT_CMP(cmp, a, b) do { switch(Assertion::GetSingleton()->checkAssertion((cmp), (a), (b), "", #a, #b, __FILE__, __LINE__)) { case 0: break; case 1: break;  case 2: abort(); } } while(0)
00045 #else
00046 #   define  ASSERT(a) do {} while(0)
00047 #   define  ASSERT_CMP(cmp, a, b) do {} while(0)
00048 #endif

00105 class Assertion : public Singleton<Assertion> {
00106 public:
00107     void setSoftAbort(bool softAbort);
00108     void getTestStats(int &made, int &passed, Real &percentage);
00109     void printTestStats();
00110 
00111 public:
00112     template <typename T1, typename T2>
00113     int checkAssertion(
00114         const std::string &cmpString,
00115         const T1 &valueOne,
00116         const T2 &valueTwo,
00117         const std::string &message,
00118         const std::string &condOne,
00119         const std::string &condTwo,
00120         const std::string &file,
00121         int line);
00122 
00123     int checkAssertion(
00124         bool valueTwo,
00125         const std::string &message,
00126         const std::string &cond,
00127         const std::string &file,
00128         int line
00129     );
00130 
00131     template <typename T1, typename T2>
00132     static std::string eq(const T1 &valueOne, const T2 &valueTwo);
00133 
00134     template <typename T1, typename T2>
00135     static std::string ne(const T1 &valueOne, const T2 &valueTwo);
00136 
00137     template <typename T1, typename T2>
00138     static std::string gt(const T1 &valueOne, const T2 &valueTwo);
00139 
00140     template <typename T1, typename T2>
00141     static std::string ge(const T1 &valueOne, const T2 &valueTwo);
00142 
00143     template <typename T1, typename T2>
00144     static std::string lt(const T1 &valueOne, const T2 &valueTwo);
00145 
00146     template <typename T1, typename T2>
00147     static std::string le(const T1 &valueOne, const T2 &valueTwo);
00148 
00149 private:
00150     static bool feq(const Real &a, const Real &b); // ==
00151     static bool fne(const Real &a, const Real &b); // !=
00152     static bool fle(const Real &a, const Real &b); // <=
00153     static bool fge(const Real &a, const Real &b); // >=
00154     static bool flt(const Real &a, const Real &b); // <
00155     static bool fgt(const Real &a, const Real &b); // >
00156 
00157 private:
00158     bool _softAssert;
00159     int _assertionsMade;
00160     int _assertionsFailed;
00161 
00162 protected:
00163     // These are protected to match the singleton pattern.
00164     Assertion();
00165     virtual ~Assertion();
00166 
00167     // The singleton must be able to call the protected contructors (only children can
00168     // make calls to protected functions, parents cannot).
00169     template <class T> friend class Singleton;
00170 };
00171 
00172 
00173 // The equality functions pass their arguements into the floating point functions and
00174 // thus must be able to cast the values to floating point values. That is why the
00175 // __garbage_cast was created. For floats and doubles nothing actually changes, but for
00176 // any other type a cast at the pointer level is performed. Obviously this is generally
00177 // a horrible horrible thing to do, but the floating point functions are never actually
00178 // called unless the values being passed in are floating point values. Therefore it
00179 // shouldn't actually have any real effect other than allowing the programs to actually
00180 // compile.
00181 template <typename T> inline
00182 Real __garbage_cast(T &val) {
00183     return *((Real*)&val);
00184 }
00185 
00186 template <> inline
00187 Real __garbage_cast<float>(float &val) {
00188     return static_cast<Real>(val);
00189 }
00190 
00191 template <> inline
00192 Real __garbage_cast<double>(double &val) {
00193     return static_cast<Real>(val);
00194 }
00195 
00196 // First of all, we want to be able to do equality comparissons on two types without
00197 // having to implement every operator. As such, each of these functions needs to be kept
00198 // separate (instead of the case statement that was used originally) and called at the
00199 // macro level (otherwise you'd get compile errors if you ever compare a type that doesn't
00200 // make use of every operator). After this, we could call the checkAssertion function
00201 // from within each of these equality operations, but that would require passing
00202 // a huge number of arguments to every function. Instead, the result of these functions
00203 // are used as input to the check assertion function.
00204 template <typename T1, typename T2> inline
00205 std::string Assertion::eq(const T1 &valueOne, const T2 &valueTwo) {
00206     if (is_float<T1>::value || is_float<T2>::value) {
00207         return feq(__garbage_cast(valueOne), __garbage_cast(valueTwo)) ? "" : "eq";
00208     }
00209 
00210     return valueOne == valueTwo ? "" : "==";
00211 }
00212 
00213 template <typename T1, typename T2> inline
00214 std::string Assertion::ne(const T1 &valueOne, const T2 &valueTwo) {
00215     if (is_float<T1>::value || is_float<T2>::value) {
00216         return fne(__garbage_cast(valueOne), __garbage_cast(valueTwo)) ? "" : "ne";
00217     }
00218 
00219     return valueOne != valueTwo ? "" : "!=";
00220 }
00221 
00222 template <typename T1, typename T2> inline
00223 std::string Assertion::gt(const T1 &valueOne, const T2 &valueTwo) {
00224     if (is_float<T1>::value || is_float<T2>::value) {
00225         return fgt(__garbage_cast(valueOne), __garbage_cast(valueTwo)) ? "" : "gt";
00226     }
00227 
00228     return valueOne > valueTwo ? "" : ">";
00229 }
00230 
00231 template <typename T1, typename T2> inline
00232 std::string Assertion::ge(const T1 &valueOne, const T2 &valueTwo) {
00233     if (is_float<T1>::value || is_float<T2>::value) {
00234         return fge(__garbage_cast(valueOne), __garbage_cast(valueTwo)) ? "" : "ge";
00235     }
00236 
00237     return valueOne >= valueTwo ? "" : ">=";
00238 }
00239 
00240 template <typename T1, typename T2> inline
00241 std::string Assertion::lt(const T1 &valueOne, const T2 &valueTwo) {
00242     if (is_float<T1>::value || is_float<T2>::value) {
00243         return flt(__garbage_cast(valueOne), __garbage_cast(valueTwo)) ? "" : "lt";
00244     }
00245 
00246     return valueOne < valueTwo ? "" : "<";
00247 }
00248 
00249 template <typename T1, typename T2> inline
00250 std::string Assertion::le(const T1 &valueOne, const T2 &valueTwo) {
00251     if (is_float<T1>::value || is_float<T2>::value) {
00252         return fle(__garbage_cast(valueOne), __garbage_cast(valueTwo)) ? "" : "le";
00253     }
00254 
00255     return valueOne <= valueTwo ? "" : "<=";
00256 }
00257 
00258 
00259 template <typename T1, typename T2> inline
00260 int Assertion::checkAssertion(
00261     const std::string &cmpString,
00262     const T1 &valueOne,
00263     const T2 &valueTwo,
00264     const std::string &message,
00265     const std::string &condOne,
00266     const std::string &condTwo,
00267     const std::string &file,
00268     int line) {
00269 
00270     _assertionsMade++;
00271     if (!cmpString.length()) { return 0; }
00272     _assertionsFailed++;
00273 
00274     bool abortOnError = LogStream::GetAbortOnError();
00275     LogStream::SetAbortOnError(false);
00276 
00277     Error("Assertion failed :" << file << ":" << line << ":");
00278     if (message.length()) {
00279         Error(message);
00280     }
00281 
00282     Error(condOne << cmpString << condTwo);
00283     Error("One:\t" << valueOne);
00284     Error("Two:\t" << valueTwo);
00285 
00286     LogStream::SetAbortOnError(abortOnError);
00287     
00288     return _softAssert ? 1 : 2;
00289 }
00290 
00291 #endif
